answer_html: so that if we wanted the nth transition probabilities we’d have tn = Pn x.
answer_latex:
so that if we wanted the \emph{n}\textsuperscript{th} transition
probabilities we'd have \textbf{t\textsubscript{n}} =
\emph{P\textsuperscript{n}} \textbf{x}.
hints_html: We know that if we start from x then Px gives us the probability of 1 transition. How do we get to two transitions?
hints_latex:
We know that if we start from \textbf{x} then P\textbf{x} gives us the
probability of 1 transition. How do we get to two transitions?
hints_raw: We know that if we start from '''x''' then P'''x''' gives us the probability of 1 transition.  How do we get to two transitions?
question: A 23
sols_html:
We are starting in state 2 so there is 100% probability of starting in state 2 and zero elsewhere, therefore our input vector is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}=\left[0,1,0\right].\end{aligned}\]

If we wanted to know the probabilities for moving one transition we would compute t1 = Px,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{t}_1=P\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10\\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10\\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} 3/10\\ 3/10\\ 4/10 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

However we want to know the probabilities for a second transition. We can think of this as a first transition of our new vector t1. Therefore the second transition probabilities are t1 = P t1,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{t}_2=P\mathbf{t}_1=\begin{bmatrix} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10\\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10\\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 3/10\\ 3/10\\ 4/10 \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} 37/100\\ 43/100\\ 20/100 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, starting in state 2, it is most likely that after two transitions, the person will still be in state 2 since 43/100 is the highest of the three probabilities.

Notice, we could also think of the problem as,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{t}_2=P\mathbf{t}_1=P(P\mathbf{x})=P^2\mathbf{x}\end{aligned}\]

so that if we wanted the nth transition probabilities we’d have tn = Pn x.
sols_raw:
We are starting in state 2 so there is 100% probability of starting in state 2 and zero elsewhere, therefore our input vector is

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=\left[0,1,0\right].
</math>

If we wanted to know the probabilities for moving one transition we would compute '''t<sub>1</sub>''' = ''P'''x''''',

:<math>
\mathbf{t}_1=P\mathbf{x}=\begin{bmatrix}
8/10  &  3/10  &  1/10\\
2/10  &  3/10  &  7/10\\
0  &  4/10  &  2/10
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
=\begin{bmatrix}
3/10\\
3/10\\
4/10
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

However we want to know the probabilities for a second transition.  We can think of this as a first transition of our new vector '''t<sub>1</sub>'''.  Therefore the second transition probabilities are '''t<sub>1</sub>''' = ''P'' '''t<sub>1</sub>''',

:<math>
\mathbf{t}_2=P\mathbf{t}_1=\begin{bmatrix}
8/10  &  3/10  &  1/10\\
2/10  &  3/10  &  7/10\\
0  &  4/10  &  2/10
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
3/10\\
3/10\\
4/10
\end{bmatrix}
=\begin{bmatrix}
37/100\\
43/100\\
20/100
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Therefore, starting in state 2, it is '''most likely that after two transitions, the person will still be in state 2''' since 43/100 is the highest of the three probabilities.

Notice, we could also think of the problem as,

:<math>
\mathbf{t}_2=P\mathbf{t}_1=P(P\mathbf{x})=P^2\mathbf{x}
</math>

so that if we wanted the ''n''<sup>th</sup> transition probabilities we'd have '''t<sub>n</sub>''' = ''P<sup>n</sup>'' '''x'''.
statement_html:
Questions A22-A24 concern a random walk with three states that has transition matrix

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{c c c} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10 \\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10 \\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

If the walker starts in state 2, which state will she most likely be in after 2 time steps?
statement_latex:
Questions A22-A24 concern a random walk with three states that has
transition matrix

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{c c c} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10 \\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10 \\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

If the walker starts in state 2, which state will she most likely be in
after 2 time steps?
statement_raw:
Questions A22-A24 concern a random walk with three states that has transition matrix

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{c c c} 8/10 & 3/10 & 1/10 \\ 2/10 & 3/10 & 7/10 \\ 0 & 4/10 & 2/10 \end{array}\right]
</math>

If the walker starts in state 2, which state will she most likely be in after 2 time steps?
